text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with sausage cheese balls
that's right tis the season to entertain
large groups of people tis also the
season to be running short on time and
money which is why a recipe like this
can be a real savior and with these
sausage cheese balls may lack in
sophistication they more than make up
for being relatively inexpensive and
very simple to make so let's go ahead
get started with one of the main
ingredients of the sausage and
traditionally this recipe is done with
breakfast sausage but personally I
prefer spicy Italian sausage for this so
that's what I have a pound and a quarter
of in this bowl and while I don't use
the breakfast sausage I will in a little
bit of an homage to the original add in
a little bit of freshly grated nutmeg
not too much just a touch we also want
to do a nice big handful of chopped
green onions as well as some grated
cheddar cheese and a lot of it and then
one great tip here if you can try to get
most of it in the bowl and in case
you're keeping score at home I'm using
extra sharp cheddar but I'm pretty sure
your favorite cheese will work so as
usual that kind of thing is up to you
you are the hey-zeus of your cheeses and
then it's time for maybe the most key
ingredient the dry biscuit mix except
that's not what I use I just use good
old-fashioned self-rising flour which
works just as good if not better and
I'll explain why on the blog post so
we'll go ahead and dump that in and then
what we want to do is mix this up with
our hand but before I start I like to
give it a brief mixing with a fork just
until everything's sort of coated with
the flour and at that point I will
switch to my bare hand which you can't
just start with but I think by giving it
a little mix with a fork first it's
going to help prevent our fingers from
getting all gunked up too quickly
so I'm gonna go ahead and switch to the
old five finger food processor and give
this a mix until it just starts to come
together at which point we're going to
stop and drizzle in two tablespoons of
milk or water and then we'll continue
mixing it until it's just combined and
we're able to form balls and while a lot
of people add that milk right at the
beginning I think all this comes
together better if you give it a mixing
first and then add the liquid okay but
anyway like I said we will continue
mixing until our ingredients are just
combined at which point we will stop
because we're done at this point we
could use it immediately or we could
wrap it up and pop it in the fridge
until needed so yes you can definitely
make this mixture ahead of time which of
course is always an advantage for
holiday entertaining but either way when
we are ready this is how I think we
should form and cook our sausage cheese
balls so what we're going to need
besides our mixture is some type of
scooper so we could get equal portions
as well as a little bit of cold water
for our fingers because as you know by
now
dab hands make smooth balls and of
course you're also going to need a
baking sheet which I've covered with
some lightly oiled foil so we'll go
ahead and we'll scoop out some mixture
and then using some very lightly
moistened hands we will roll those into
balls and place those down nice and
evenly spaced on our baking sheet and by
the way I should mention there are many
many different formulas for this recipe
with all kinds of different ratios
between the sausage and the cheese and
the biscuit mix so that is another thing
we can discuss on the blog and by
discuss I mean argue but I guess the
point is no matter what specific recipe
you use the technique is pretty much the
same and then once we do have a pan of
our sausage cheese balls successfully
prepped we are ready to bake these up in
a surprisingly hot oven we're going to
go ahead and transfer these into the
center of a 450 degree oven for about 12
minutes or until cooked through and if
you offer that last minute or two of
cooking time you can switch your oven to
broil to give these a little extra color
and after about 12 minutes in the oven
Plus minute of optional broiling they
should look something like this
oh man those look good and then once
these are out of the oven we have to let
them sit for exactly five minutes before
we try to pull them off the foil if not
they're probably still going to be stuck
and they might tear so give them five
minutes and once they've cooled down
just a little bit they should come off
very easily and as you can see those
bottoms have formed a glorious shiny
crispy crust oh yeah and I really should
let these cool down a little more before
I take a bite but I'm not going to
because they look and smell too good and
these really are quite interesting and I
mean the good interesting not the air
quotes interesting they are cheesy bread
and sausage e all at the same time so
this point we'll go ahead and transfer
those onto some more appropriate serving
platter usually along with some kind of
dip for me it's just a simple mustard
mayo or as they call it the world of
casual dining
Dijonnaise and by the way if you haven't
had these before
and you're imagining something light and
tender these are not that these are
actually fairly firm and dense which is
why I think they're so perfect to serve
to people that are drinking in fact that
reminds me don't serve these and sober
people the subtleties will be lost on
them and by the way when I mentioned
they form a nice crispy crust on the
bottom I wasn't kidding check it out and
I would have done that harder but I was
afraid to break in the plate but anyway
that's it
sausage cheese balls just a very tasty
ball and surprisingly addictive and
please if you're bothered by that double
dip you just saw don't be I'm gonna eat
this whole plate myself that's how good
they are and I'm not even drinking
allegedly so I really do hope you give
these a try soon head over to food
wishes calm for all the agreed amounts
and more info as usual and as always
enjoy
you
